ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes, of course--I definitely feel like I know about 100 times more about 19th century French lit than before. Also, the class is set up to help you write a decent seminar paper (which is all about generating ideas for a seminar paper), and I appreciated that very much

We covered French literary works spanning the 19th century and discussed them in relation to the broader theme of modernity. I would recommend the course. It helped me view the literature I want to study in the larger context of changes occurring in France though the 19th century (other than political revolutions, which has tended to be most of the context I've been given in the past).

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Good intro to an entire body of literature that I should know way more about. Definitely an essential skill also to be able to generously reproduce the arguments of critical texts--which we practiced every week. Also, working on 20th century novels, essential to know Balzac, Flaubert, and Zola. In that way, I will definitely be able to use this course in the future

I hope to focus on 19th-century French literature, so there was really no element of this course which was not relevant for me. I do not know how it will help me specifically, but it certainly deepened my knowledge of the period and literature I want to study in a very helpful way.
